; syn. by Drake & Hottes, 1950: 177

subSubSection.paragraph:

15 May 1992
, coll. unknown ( ZRC )
.

Johor
: 1 female , swamp forest stream 27 km SW of Mersing ,
14 Aug.1985
, CL 2058, coll. D. A. & J. T
.
Polhemus ( JTPC )
.

EAST TIMOR ,
Dili Dist .
: 3 males , 1 female , Tasitolu wetland complex, W. of Dili , middle lake, sea level, 8°33'43"S , 125°30'29"E , water temp. 32°C., salinity 75 ppt.,
1 Sep.2004
, 1130–1200 hours., CL 7310, coll. D. A. Polhemus ( USNM , BPBM )
.

12 Dec.1965
, B. M. 1966-1, collector unknown ( JTPC )
.

Fukuoka Pref.

7 Jun.1929

.

.],

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 20.
Saldula sonneveldti
, dorsal habitus. Specimen from Malaysia, Kelantan, E. of Kota Bharu, CL 2083.

Fig. 21.
Micracanthia ornatula
, dorsal habitus. Specimen from East Timor, Tasitolu wetland complex, west of Dili, CL 7310.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. — Male length 2.90–3.20, maximum width (across hemelytra) 1.30–1.50; female length 3.50–3.60, maximum width (across hemelytra) 1.40–1.60. Head, pronotum and scutellum black; hemelytra black, broadly marked with dark yellow patches on outer corium external to vein R + M, and with smaller dark yellow spots on inner corium and posterior end of clavus; wing membrane pale translucent fumate, veins contrastingly dark; antennae with segment I yellowish brown, segments II–IV darker brown; legs pale yellow basally, becoming pale brown distally.

Distribution. — Originally described from northern Africa (Nubia) by Reuter (1881) , and widespread in the Eastern Hemisphere. Recorded by Schuh et al. (1987) from South Africa , Angola , Tanzania , Sudan , Egypt , Mongolia , India , Ceylon , Burma , and the Philippines , with further records provided by J. Polhemus & D. Polhemus (1999) from Oman , Saudi Arabia , China , Taiwan , Thailand , Laos , Vietnam , Borneo, Indonesia , Papua New Guinea , and Australia . We now provide the first records for Singapore and Peninsular Malaysia , East Timor , New Caledonia , Japan , Madagascar , Reunion, Sierra Leone , Upper Volta , Kenya , and Pakistan .

Discussion. — Recognised by its small size (less than 4 mm in both sexes) and predominantly dark colouration, with the head and thorax uniformly rugose, punctate and dull. The records given above for Singapore and Malaysia are the first for this species in those countries, but are not unexpected given the very wide range of this small, highly dispersive species. For a more detailed treatment of the complex synonymy of
Salda dixoni
under this species see Schuh et al. (1987: 339) .
